outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: It’s a Small World of Ice and Fire
Who Will Survive Season 8? Network Positions that Kill

all_paragraphs: In Episode 1 we’ll take a bird’s-eye look at the evolving character co-occurrence network using graphs that animate the “topology” of the entire network across all seven seasons. These graphs will also show us how characters’ positions shift within the network as the story unfolds.
Before digging in, a little about the guts of the graphs to help interpret them.

Nodes. Nodes represent individual characters, of which there are 557 over the seven seasons. To give a sense of each character’s significance, nodes are larger for characters who appear in more scenes, and green for main —147 regular and recurring — characters. Nodes for minor characters are pink and, of course, small.

Characters enter the network when they first appear in a scene and exit when they are killed or otherwise die (the fate of 100 main characters). Minor characters also exit if they do not appear for five consecutive episodes and do not later reappear. Those who do later reappear remain and absent connections drift toward the center of the graph until they reappear and reconnect.

Edges. Edges connect characters who co-appear in particular scenes. Among the 557 characters there are 3,849 edges (~7/character). Edges are added when characters first appear together in a scene. Edges between main characters are considered permanent — once two main characters have co-appeared an edge connects them unless one or both is killed or dies. Edges involving minor characters are removed if the characters do not co-appear for five consecutive episodes, or one or both exit the network. This difference reflects the likely persistence of ties between main characters despite not having recently co-appeared—for example, ties among Stark or Lannister family members despite the separate (and disconnected) paths they travel.

The edges also signal the nature of ties. Thicker edges indicate more frequent co-appearances, and so “stronger” ties. The tenor of ties is reflected in their color, with redder (bluer) edges indicating more (less) frequent co-appearance in armed scenes, and so more combative (cordial) relationships. Purplish edges mix of friendly and hostile co-appearances, and so may reflect either friends fighting foes together, or friends later becoming foes (or vice-versa).

Layouts. Graphs are generated using a “Force-Directed” algorithm in which unconnected nodes are pushed apart and connected nodes are pulled together. This gives meaning to the location of characters in the graph. Characters colocated in the graph co-appear in scenes together more frequently. And, when a set of characters tend to co-appear frequently with each other, these characters will cluster together. Characters who co-appear with characters who tend not to co-appear occupy positions between these characters who are themselves located in different regions of the graph.

Now you know all you need to “read” the graph, and give meaning to the characters’ positions and movement within the graph over time. Watch the graph animation a few times to see if you can track the unfolding story line in the graph, and make sense of the evolving network.
Several features of the graph will be of interest to us in future episodes. I’ll introduce a couple of them here so we can dig more deeply (and precisely) into them (and others) in later episodes.

Cliques. One notable feature is that the network is characterized for much of the series by a “cliquey” structure in which relatively distinct clusters of characters play out story lines — some much more violent than others, as edge colors reveal — centered on the main characters anchoring them.

These “cliques”, and their central characters, are more easily seen in the next graph, in which clusters of characters who frequently co-appear with one another are colored similarly. Because their members co-appear primarily with each other, these cliques (and their members) are relatively isolated from each other within the network — the clique centered on Daenerys Targaryen being the most isolated.

A transition in the graph’s topology occurs during Season 7 as the graph converges into a single clique comprised of all the main characters. This transition reflects the merging of the previously separate story lines and their central characters into a single alliance in the face of the growing White Walker threat.

Small Worlds. A second is that, prior to the convergence in Season 7, several main characters, rather than belonging to a clique, straddle them, linking their story lines and connecting their main characters into a single network graph. Tyrion Lannister, for example, bridges multiple cliques across the network, as does Theon Greyjoy. Others, Jon Snow, for instance, both center a clique, and bridge between them.

This topology—densely interconnected cliques linked by a small number of bridges — is signature “small world” networks, which are ubiquitous in social (as well as biological and technical) systems. And so it is intriguing to see this topology also arise in these fictitious Lands, with or without the intention of the series’ creators/writers.

In a small world network, despite most nodes connected primarily to a relatively small number of other nodes within a clique, the paths between them are short as a result of a small number of nodes that “bridge” the cliques. Small World network structures exhibit important features, including rapid spread of information through the network in only a few steps, and robustness to the loss of nodes, most of which have little effect on the length of paths or cliquey-ness of the network.

This robustness is apparent both when Eddard (Ned) Stark loses his head and his wife and son, Catelyn and Robb, meet the ends at the “Red Wedding”. As evident in the animations, the graph’s topology is altered little by their exits. Because the characters they co-appeared with also tended to co-appear with each other (their edges are relatively uniform in color — Ned, purple; Catelyn and Robb, green), their edges are “redundant” and the network topology robust to their demise.

In contrast, the edges of a “bridging” character like Tyrion Lannister who co-appears with characters who tend not to co-appear with each other (and so his edges are multicolored) are not redundant, and their loss can alter the topology dramatically.

(World without Tyrion. To illustrate this, I’ve posted a graph in which Tyrion is given the “George-Bailey-It’s-A-Wonderful-Life” treatment. With his node and all its edges removed, the center of the graph is largely vacant and cliques nearly disconnected (but for Theon Greyjoy, especially after the Red Wedding), and remains so until the Season 7 convergence… much of which depended on Tyrion’s connections, and so unlikely in his absence. You can view it here.)

Transient Ties. Another way to highlight these network features is to graph the co-appearance network within narrower time-windows of the story by dropping all edges—for main and minor characters — if the characters do not co-appear in five consecutive episodes, or either or both characters exit.

Because this graph is drawn based on recent co-appearances — active ties — the sparseness of connections between cliques is more apparent, as are the bridge characters who jump from clique to clique as they spin their webs of connections with characters across the network. Watch, for example, Tyrion Lannister move the though the network over time. The result is his central position in the earlier graphs which assume these connections are persistent rather than short-lived.

In the next episode (link below), I’ll look in more detail at the “statistical mechanics” of the global network’s structural characteristics, quantifying its various features — density, clustering, path length, and small worldliness— and perhaps begin digging into the network positions and ties of some of the main characters.
New to GoT Season 7.5? Check out the Trailer here, and the Episodes:
Episode 1 — Graphing the Big Picture
Episode 2 — It’s a Small World of Ice and Fire
Episode 3 — Character Network Positions and Advantages
Episode 4 — Who Will Survive Season 8? Network Positions that Kill
Have an idea for a “by request” episode? Leave a comment and I’ll see what I can do…

Professor, Rotman School of Management; Student of Strategic Organization & Social Networks; Author of EPINETS
